content.content: Overview Pro: The decrease of the tin will allow a better peg currently around 1.003~ 1.004 Cons: The decrease will bring less income from the PSM PSM tin Please vote for all options you would support in an onchain poll     0.1% (no change) 0.07% 0.05% 0.03% Abstain     0 voters     Next Steps The Poll will run until February 12th; if its outcome is a positive feedback it will result in a signal request poll.

The post presents pros and cons of the proposal and asks readers to vote for their preferred option. The poll will run until February 12th, and if the outcome is positive, it will result in a signal request poll. The post invites readers to provide feedback, ask questions, and offer constructive criticism.

content.content: You need to replace the poll, it won’t let you edit it after 5mins so authors can’t manipulate the options after people have voted for them. If you add name=poll2 into the poll, it will treat it as a new poll, clear the votes, and will allow you to change the options. I’m not sure it’s necessarily a good idea to change the tin and tout separately though. It might be, but I’d like to see some discussion on that before we just go and change one of them independently from the other. Could we maybe start a discussion thread first and poll once we have a better idea of the options and the potential consequences?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Thanks, Can I change it to informal?
Yeah, that’s fine. If you do that, take out the ‘Next Steps’ section though, informal polls don’t lead to on-chain polls.

Another con is we take on more uncompensated USDC exposure. Actually I think that is a bigger con than the reduced fee income from PSM trades. I don’t think we should look at the PSM as a revenue stream, because every time it is utilized, we are exchanging speculators’ faith in the peg for current income. While I am not opposed in theory to tighter bounds on the PSM, I think it’s important that we have a lot of PSM debt headroom when we do it. Speculators are more likely to help soft-arb the peg when they are confident Maker has the firepower to step in and do it themselves otherwise. When the PSM is maxed out, its peg-stabilizing ability is neutered, and so it is risky for speculators to participate. Ideally we have a lot of un-utilized DC in the PSM; it represents a $500M “promise” from Maker to enforce bounds on the price of Dai if all else fails. We also don’t know that much about the demand for PSM trades at different price levels yet. It’s possible that there’s a few $100M of demand around 1.00025 which could result in a maxed out PSM. But I think that’s less likely with a looser bound around 1.0005-1.0010.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: I see the PSM as a buffer, and the dai which is not inside the psm is just somewhere else. Also regarding our exposure, the percentage of USDC has decrease significantly and I believe it gives us a bit more room. Tho I agree it is not a significant revenue stream. One of the reason why I started this poll is to let people know that we are not accepting a Dai at 1.0015 especially with a USDC vault at 0% and a PSM, this should not happen, but it happened today. The reality is that with a high price for the gas a PSM at 1.001 is indirectly a PSM at 1.0015 or even higher and either we take on our fees or we let the dai going up. I believe if we do the second it is going to be even worse. furthermore I don’t think by going to 1.0005 we will change significatively the selling line due to the high transaction price.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback
